title.text: SemEval 2015 Task 18: Broad-Coverage Semantic Dependency Parsing

abstractContent.text: Task 18 at SemEval 2015 defines Broad-Coverage Semantic Dependency Parsing (SDP) as the problem of recovering sentence-internal predicate-argument relationships for all content words, i.e. the semantic structure constituting the relational core of sentence meaning.

In this task description, we position the problem in comparison to other language analysis sub-tasks, introduce and compare the semantic dependency target representations used, and summarize the task setup, participating systems , and main results.

tableCaptions.text: Table 1: Contrastive high-level graph statistics across target representations, languages, and domains.
Table 2: Pairwise F 1 similarities, including punctua- tion (upper right diagonals) or not (lower left).

Table 3: Results of the gold track (marked "), open track (marked *) and closed track (unmarked) submissions  for the English in-domain (top) and out-of-domain (bottom) data. For each system, the second column (LF)  indicates the averaged LF score across all representations, used to rank the systems. The best closed track  scores are highlighted in italices.
